ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
At PKC 2006, Chevallier–Mames, Paillier, and Pointcheval proposed discrete logarithm based encryption schemes that are partially homomorphic, either additively or multiplicatively and announced an open problem: finding a discrete logarithm based cryptosystem that would help realize fully additive or multiplicative homomorphism. In this study, we achieve this goal by enclosing two opposite settings on the discrete logarithm problems (DLP) simultaneously: the first setting is that DLP over
Z
p
0
(where p 0 − 1 is smooth) is used to encode messages, while the second setting is that DLP over
Z
p
(where p − 1 is non-smooth, i.e., containing large prime factors) is used to encrypt plaintexts. Then, based on the proposed scheme, novel protocols for secure data aggregation in wireless sensor networks are presented. Finally, taking Paillier’s factoring-based additively homomorphic encryption schemes as the reference framework, we present detailed performance comparisons and further enhancement.

ce:section.ce:para: In general, we expect a cryptosystem to be as secure as possible. To this end, various security notions have been developed. The basic requirement for a cryptosystem is that adversaries must be prevented from learning confidential messages. This is the so-called security notion of one-wayness (OW) and was recognized even before 2500 B.C. With the development of modern cryptography, particularly after the advent of public-key cryptosystems [8], new desirable security notions were conceived. Naor suggested that different security notions for encryption should be defined by orthogonally considering the various possible goals and the various possible attack models [2]. Typically, two goals, namely, indistinguishability (IND) [14] and non-malleability (NM) [10], and three attack models, namely, chosen-plaintext attack (CPA), non-adaptive chosen-ciphertext attack (CCA1) [21], and adaptive chosen-ciphertext attack (CCA2) [27], have been considered. Currently, IND-CCA, especially IND-CCA2, is known to be the most desirable security property for many applied cryptosystems.

However, we have seen a lot of applications in which certain transformations on ciphertexts before decryption could be expected. Thus, encryption schemes with IND-CCA security are not flexible enough to be used in these scenarios. The primitive of homomorphic encryption enables blind transformations on plaintexts via (possibly different) algebraic operations on ciphertexts [16,6]. Depending upon the specific viewpoint, this is either a positive or a negative attribute of a cryptosystem. Homomorphic encryption schemes are inherently malleable and are thus unsuitable in scenarios in which modifications to ciphertexts are forbidden. On the other hand, the homomorphic property is useful for building secure voting and lottery protocols [17], auction protocols [32], private information retrieval [22], Fingerprinting protocol [18], buyer–seller watermarking protocol in the encrypted domain [33], etc. At PKC 2006, Chevallier–Mames, Paillier, and Pointcheval [6] proposed discrete logarithm based (DL-based) encryption schemes that are partially homomorphic, either additively or multiplicatively, and finally announced an open research problem: finding a DL-based cryptosystem that helps realize fully additive or multiplicative homomorphism.

We apply the proposed additively homomorphic encryption to design novel protocols for secure data aggregation in wireless sensor networks.

We would like to mention two other related but different topics. First, factoring-based additively homomorphic encryption is an intensively studied and well-developed topic. For instances, Goldwasser and Micali [15] (in 1984), Benaloh [3] (in 1994) and Paillier [23] (in 1999) have already made respective contributions on additively homomorphic encryption schemes based on factoring-related assumptions. Second, our proposal is a fully solution for DL-based additively homomorphic encryption, instead of a fully homomorphic encryption (FHE). More recently, the primitive of FHE attracts a lot of attention, such as Gentry’s construction over idea lattice [13], Dijk et al.’s construction over integers [9], etc. Here, we would like to point out that the semantic of the adverb “fully” in the phrase “fully homomorphic encryption” is fundamentally different from what we consider in this paper: in our consideration, we follow Chevallier–Mames et al.’s idea [6,4] and use the phrase “fully additively homomorphic encryption” in which the adverb “fully” means that the additive homomorphism on encrypted data is performed on entire message space, instead of on partial message space; However, the primitive of FHE means an encryption scheme that supports several algebraic homomorphic operations, typically addition and multiplication, simultaneously. To the best of our knowledge, finding either factoring-based FHE or DL-based FHE, even additively homomorphic encryption with d-operand multiplications [20], is still a challenge.

A very typical application of homomorphic encryption in practice is data aggregation in wireless sensor networks (WSN) [29,7,31,5,19]. Aggregation techniques are used to reduce the amount of data communicated within a WSN so as to conserve battery power [19]. For instance, in order to obtain temperature or humidity information within an area, a group of distribute sensors need to periodically report and collectively process their data for yielding valuable information of the entire WSN, by such operations as average and variance, and so on [5]. One natural approach to data aggregation is to simply add up values as they are forwarded toward the sink. Homomorphic encryption allows some types of statistical computations on encrypted data, similar to those on plaintext data [12], thereby offering significant advantages in securing WSN data aggregation by preventing eavesdropping attacks. Without homomorphic encryption, the intermediate sensors must have access to the secret keys in order to decrypt the collected data before performing aggregation. However, storing sensitive information such as secret keys inside the intermediate sensors is vulnerable to many attacks [5]. Once the secret keys are exposed, the network is no longer secure. Homomorphic encryption prevents this problem since sensitive information is not stored on the intermediate sensors [5].

While it is intuitive to use homomorphic encryption for secure data aggregation in WSN, there is no silver bullet application has been seen so far, and the majority of available schemes are vulnerable to some extent. For example, in [5], an additively homomorphic encryption for WSN data aggregation was proposed. The scheme is essentially a stream cipher and its homomorphic property relies on the synchronization among the key-stream generators, i.e., all sensors in the field must share the same key-stream generator. Clearly, this is impractical in a distributed environment. More seriously, this approach has two fundamental flaws: (1) it is difficult to ensure the confidentiality of this commonly shared key-stream generator and (2) the scheme would be insecure if some sensors that have access to the key-stream generator were colluded by the adversaries. Therefore, to achieve secure WSN data aggregation, we prefer homomorphic public-key encryption (Hom-PKE) than secret-key encryption. In public-key encryption, no secret is embedded in the sensors, and thus, this scheme is immune to colluding attacks. Vaidehi [12] tried to solve this problem by using a privacy homomorphism called DF-a-New-PH. However, we found that DF-a-New-PH does not have the expected effect of encryption for two reasons: (1) some secret parameters can be easily computed from the public parameters and (2) all secret parameters are explicitly involved in the encryption algorithm. We know that no public-key encryption scheme can operate in this manner. DF-a-New-PH is essentially an encoding/decoding system rather than a cryptosystem since it does not preserve confidentiality. In DF-a-New-PH, all secrets can be made public. When using Hom-PKE, a malicious node can still insert junk data to disturb the aggregation, although this problem is not specific to Hom-PKE. All encryption schemes, public-key or secret-key, are vulnerable to this kind of attack. In terms of consequence, this kind of attack can lead to denial of service (DOS). However, how to resist DOS attacks is another significant research topic that is beyond the scope of this paper.

In this paper, we first try to answer the open problem raised by Chevallier–Mames, Paillier, and Pointcheval [6] (at PKC 2006), i.e., finding a DL-based additively homomorphic encryption scheme. We achieve this goal by lifting the message space in the ElGamal scheme from

Then, based on the proposed scheme, we design novel protocols for securely and blindly (i.e., without knowing the plaintexts) calculating summation, expectation, variance, maximum and minimum in a WSN scenario. Finally, taking Paillier’s factoring-based additively homomorphic encryption schemes as the reference framework, we give performance comparisons in detail. We also propose a fast variant scheme by combining Paillier’s idea into our proposal.

The remaining sections are organized as follows: The preliminaries are given in Section 2. In Section 3, our main contribution, i.e., a DL-based additively homomorphic encryption scheme, is developed step-by-step. In Section 4, the problem of message overflow and countermeasures are discussed in detail. Based on our proposal, novel protocols for secure WSN data aggregation are described in Section 5. Performance evaluation and a fast variant scheme are given in Section 6. Finally, the concluding remarks are given in Section 7. All related proofs, algorithms, parameters, etc., are arranged in Appendixes.

We at first follow Chevallier–Mames et al. [6] to give a simple introduction on the concept of public-key encryption and the related security notions, and then give a review on the definition of the discrete logarithm problems, its intractability, as well as the related cryptographic assumptions. Readers familiar to these knowledge please go to Section 3 directly.

It is further taken as a design basis for novel protocols for secure WSN data aggregation. Performance evaluation indicates that our protocols can obtain a near 46.9% accelerating ratio in encryption and a 50% accelerating ratio in decryption at the expense of merely two times ciphertext length than that of Paillier’s factoring-based additively homomorphic encryption scheme.
